newsitem.title: HONG KONG: Shenzhen B index up at noon but mood jittery.
newsitem.headline: Shenzhen B index up at noon but mood jittery.

text.p: Shenzhen's B share index was up slightly at midday on Friday after a rumoured market clampdown failed to materialise, but trading was thin and volatile, analysts said.
The foreign currency B share index gained 1.06 points or 0.60 percent to 177.66 on turnover of HK$47.4 million.
"The index rose because the expected bad news did not materialise," an analyst at J&A Securities said.
A Hong Kong newspaper said on Thursday that China's Ministry of Finance was considering increasing stamp tax on stock trading to 0.4 or 0.5 percent from the current 0.3 percent.

"The small trading volume shows investors are cautious after yesterday's sharp losses," an analyst at China Guotai Securities said. Shenzhen B shares fell 3.35 percent on Thursday due to fears of a government crackdown.
"Monday's performance will depend on whether Beijing comes out with any measures over the weekend," the Guotai analyst said.
On Thursday, the B index fell 3.35 percent to 176.61 following the A share index which tumbled 5.97 percent to close at 501.92.
Analysts said they expect narrow-range trading for the B index in the afternoon, with the wait-and-see mood persisting.
By midday, the domestic currency A share index had gained 7.39 points or 1.47 percent to 509.30 on turnover of 7.89 billion yuan.
Jiangling Motors Corp was among the sharpest gainers in both the A and B share markets.
Its B shares surged HK$0.29 or 7.88 percent to HK$3.97 while its A shares rose to its 10 percent limit-up at 8.66 yuan.
